"We watched the video from Fulton Country Ga, where the poll observers were sent home and then tens of thousands of ballots were pulled out from under tables in containers that had been preplaced there early in the morning. We watched as the vote count took over a week in several swing states, even though the vote counting machines can process hundreds of thousands of votes per hour. Obama turned over all of his records to NARA in 2017, upon the end of Obama‚Äôs term, and they remain in NARA‚Äôs sole custody, in accordance with federal law. Some 30 million documents were moved to a NARA-operated facility in the Chicago area, as the agency explained in a statement Friday, but none were classified. The administration‚Äôs classified documents are stored in a separate NARA facility in the Washington, D.C., area.
Presidential libraries are managed by NARA, and the documents therein belong to the agency, which also manages related public records requests. But the Obama Presidential Library has no physical location; it‚Äôs the first to be wholly virtual. Some 95 percent of Obama administration documents were ‚Äúborn digital,‚Äù meaning they have no ‚Äúhard-copy‚Äù version and don‚Äôt need to be digitized, per NARA.
Separately, construction began in 2021 on the Obama Presidential Center, a complex in Chicago managed by the privately-run Obama Foundation. But because the center will not be affiliated with NARA, the Obama Foundation will need to request to borrow any artifacts or records intended for display there from the government. The foundation did provide funding to NARA for digitizing the Obama administration‚Äôs paper documents, but NARA itself is responsible for actually handling them, according to the agency.

Specifically, it pointed out that Section E of the Espionage Act, one of the three laws Trump is suspected of having violated, makes it a crime to retain any government records pertaining to the US's national defense, regardless of classification level.
The other two federal statutes Trump's suspected of having broken ‚Äî 18 USC Section 2071 and 18 USC Section 1519 ‚Äî criminalize the concealment, removal, and destruction of government records, also regardless of classification level.
In its Tuesday filing, the government argued that the issues Trump has raised with respect to his request for a special master are "ultimately ireelevant."
"Even if Plaintiff had declassified these records, and even if he somehow had categorized them as his 'personal' records for purposes of the [Presidential Records Act] ‚Äî neither of which has been shown ‚Äî nothing in the PRA or any other source of law establishes a plausible claim of privilege or any other justification for an injunction restricting the government's review and use of records at the center of an ongoing criminal and national security investigation," prosecutors said.
"And nothing in Plaintiff's Response rebuts the compelling public interest in granting the limited stay the government seeks," they added.
